posts.body:
Great Lake Smithing

Ancient Native Americans were some of first coppersmiths in the world. Prehistoric copper mining began about 9,500 years ago, by what is known as the Old Copper Culture. This culture peaked around 6,000 years ago and dissolved–or at least stopped working with copper, about 5,400 years ago. This suggests that American copperworking is older even then Middle Eastern copperworking, where the oldest copper artifact is a pendant only 8,700 years old.

The copper was used to make tools, weapons for hunting and fishing, and beads and bracelets. This culture was so prolific that their relics are everywhere–people living in this space now may have buckets of copper artifacts they’ve uncovered.

It is incredibly unusual that they stopped, as most societies ‘progressed’ from stone to bronze to iron. However, this is a system that really only applies to prehistoric Europe, the Mediterranean, and the Near East. It’s essentially useless for most of Africa, much of Asia, and all of the Americas.

The return to stone and bone tools is like due to how Great Lakes copper is purer–and thus softer–than the copper mined elsewhere in the world. It required more work but did not perform significantly better. Instead of showing a 'progression’ and 'regression’ of this society, it shows they were intelligent and experimental–even after most tools were stone, the Old Copper Culture continued to use copper awls, which did perform better than stone in controlled laboratory tests.

posts.body:
Stories of the Squamish

The Squamish of the Pacific Coast (Skwxwú7mesh, sometimes transliterated as Sko-ko-mish) have an extensive history and mythology transmitted by oral tradition.

The main spiritual beings are the Transformers (common in main indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest, though some traditions have a single Transformer). Here, the three Transformers are brothers, sent by the creator and able to transform people into other things.

The Squamish origin story says that the world was first water, and the land rose out of the water. Then appeared the first man, named X̱i7lánexw. He was given a wife, an adze (a type of ax), and a salmon trap.

As time passed, X̱i7lánexw knew that something was coming, but not what it was. At the same time, it seemed his wife was in pain, but he did not know why. In preparation for whatever was coming, he began to prepare. The three Transformer brothers came down the river where he had been, and he called them his grandchildren and fed them soup.

The lead Transformer bade his brothers scrape the bark off a nearby tree. They took the bark from a willow and made willow bark tea, which they gave to the women. Then the lead had his brothers and X̱i7lánexw stay outside, and the woman gave birth to a baby boy. The Transformers taught the man and woman about childcare and medicine, and not long later the woman had a baby girl.

posts.body:
The Puebloans

The Pueblo are a people from what is now northern New Mexico and Arizona especially known for their beautiful style of architecture.

The Pueblo are the descendants of three major cultures: the Mogollon, the Hohokam, and the Ancestral Puebloan Culture. These left a tradition of agriculture, housing, and irrigation still used.

Around 700 CE, the Puebloan civilization was growing and centralizing. By 1050 CE, they developed the large apartment-style terraced buildings on the side of ledges. The largest, Pueblo Bonito, may have housed as many as 1000 people in a single building. This is typical of the American Southwest and Mexico–while growing European cities at the time simply added new things without much forethought, American civilizations were experts at urban planning.

The Puebloan material culture included basket weaving, pottery making, woodcarving, and had famously beautiful and decorated clothing.

Politically, Pueblo society functioned rather like city-states. Each pueblo was an independent entity with one chief (or two, one for summer and one for winter) and a religious society that helped govern internal affairs.

posts.body:
The Haudenosaunee

The Haudenosaunee, sometimes called the Iroquois Confederacy, were a confederacy of five (now six) Native American nations. From the northeast Woodlands and speaking Iroquoian languages, the Haudenosaunee are an example of a complex and effective democracy that lasted for hundreds of years.

I’ve already written about the founders of the confederation here, so rather than repeat the political details, this post will focus on family structure and culture.

The Haudenosaunee contains six groups: the Mohawk, Oneida, Onondaga, Cayuga, Seneca, and Tuscarora. These Nations are internally divided into clans, each clan with an animal name, and sometimes further divided into three sub-clans. These are family connections across nations–a wolf clan member of the Mohawk and a wolf clan member of the Seneca are relatives (and thus forbidden from marriage). Family names and clans are matrilineal.

This system was useful in many ways. It prevented incest (at a time when European monarchs were still actively encouraging it) and provided a large extended family. This was especially useful during travel when someone could find their family members in other nations and be cared for.

The Haudenosaunee languages are currently at different stages of health. Mohawk, the healthiest, has 3,000 fluent speakers while the Tuscarora language, Skarure, has declared extinct in late 2020. However, young members of the tribe are working with speakers of similar languages and Elders to revive it.

Iroquoian languages are polysynthetic, meaning a single word has many morphemes and can carry a very specific meaning. A single Mohawk word, for example, might translate to English as a full sentence.

The Haudenosaunee has 13 ceremonies in a year, following a lunar calendar. Many of them are celebrations of thanksgiving to specific crops, like Strawberry Ceremony (Mid-May) and String Bean Ceremony (Early August). Ceremonies begin and end with a prayer and include dances, songs, and storytelling.

Wampum belts are used to narrate history, traditions, and laws. Wampum beads are made from a clamshell through a long and difficult process. Beads could be white for peace or purple for more serious matters. Wampum served as a signal of authority. They are still in use and still being made, but wampum strings are now more commonly used. See the Hiawatha Belt here. See the Dust Fan Beltt below.

[Image description: a large, wide belt made of small shells. It has a brown border and a repeating triangle pattern on a white background]

The Dust Fan Belt, currently kept by the Onondaga Nation. It represents the Tree of Peace from the life of the Peacemaker and the founding of the confederacy, and “sweeping away the dust” so the council can see the best way forward for their people.

[Image description: a large, wide belt made of small shells. It has a brown border and a repeating triangle pattern on a white background]

The Dust Fan Belt, currently kept by the Onondaga Nation. It represents the Tree of Peace from the life of the Peacemaker and the founding of the confederacy, and “sweeping away the dust” so the council can see the best way forward for their people.
trail.content:
The Haudenosaunee

The Haudenosaunee, sometimes called the Iroquois Confederacy, were a confederacy of five (now six) Native American nations. From the northeast Woodlands and speaking Iroquoian languages, the Haudenosaunee are an example of a complex and effective democracy that lasted for hundreds of years.

I’ve already written about the founders of the confederation here, so rather than repeat the political details, this post will focus on family structure and culture.

The Haudenosaunee contains six groups: the Mohawk, Oneida, Onondaga, Cayuga, Seneca, and Tuscarora. These Nations are internally divided into clans, each clan with an animal name, and sometimes further divided into three sub-clans. These are family connections across nations–a wolf clan member of the Mohawk and a wolf clan member of the Seneca are relatives (and thus forbidden from marriage). Family names and clans are matrilineal.

This system was useful in many ways. It prevented incest (at a time when European monarchs were still actively encouraging it) and provided a large extended family. This was especially useful during travel when someone could find their family members in other nations and be cared for.

The Haudenosaunee languages are currently at different stages of health. Mohawk, the healthiest, has 3,000 fluent speakers while the Tuscarora language, Skarure, has declared extinct in late 2020. However, young members of the tribe are working with speakers of similar languages and Elders to revive it.

Iroquoian languages are polysynthetic, meaning a single word has many morphemes and can carry a very specific meaning. A single Mohawk word, for example, might translate to English as a full sentence.

The Haudenosaunee has 13 ceremonies in a year, following a lunar calendar. Many of them are celebrations of thanksgiving to specific crops, like Strawberry Ceremony (Mid-May) and String Bean Ceremony (Early August). Ceremonies begin and end with a prayer and include dances, songs, and storytelling.

Wampum belts are used to narrate history, traditions, and laws. Wampum beads are made from a clamshell through a long and difficult process. Beads could be white for peace or purple for more serious matters. Wampum served as a signal of authority. They are still in use and still being made, but wampum strings are now more commonly used. See the Hiawatha Belt here. See the Dust Fan Beltt below.

[Image description: a large, wide belt made of small shells. It has a brown border and a repeating triangle pattern on a white background]

The Dust Fan Belt, currently kept by the Onondaga Nation. It represents the Tree of Peace from the life of the Peacemaker and the founding of the confederacy, and “sweeping away the dust” so the council can see the best way forward for their people.

posts.body:
The Taíno

The Taíno were one of many indigenous peoples of the Caribbean islands. They lived on the islands we now call Cuba, Hispaniola (Dominican Republic and Haiti), Jamaica, Puerto Rico, the Bahamas, and the northern Lesser Antilles. Many people are the descendants of the historical Taíno and still identify as such.

The Taíno and other groups who spoke languages also from the Arawakan language family and developed a unique culture on the islands. They moved up from coastal South America using shore-hopping boats.

Taíno society was divided into two classes: nitaínos (nobles) and naborias (commoners) and were rules by caciques. The ruling was done by males, but Taíno observed a matrilineal system of kinship and inheritance. Like many other matrilineal societies, the primary male parental figure was the maternal uncle.

Taíno people often lived in a large, circular communal housing space and slept on hammocks. In fact, they invented hammocks, now a common item and essential on ships. The word barbecue is also a Taíno invention, from the barbacoa style of cooking. Other Taíno words now commonly used in English include kanoa (canoe), tabaco (tobacco), and juracán (hurricane).

An important cultural event was batey, a game using a rubber ball in a rectangular court. They were open to men and women, often used as conflict resolution, and occasionally the subject of wagers and gambling.

The Taíno were the first Americans that Christopher Columbus met on his travels across the Atlantic. He found them to be generous and kind and immediately responded with cultural destruction, violence, and brutal slavery. At the time, the island of Hispaniola alone likely had up to one million people (by some estimates, but even ‘safer’ estimates say at least half a million). The quick genocide is one of the most brutal and efficient in history, and resulted in multiple armed rebellions by Taíno and sympathetic Spaniards alike.

posts.body:
History of Ancient Hawai'i

The Hawaiian Islands were first settled by Polynesian voyagers from the Marquesas Islands. Historians do not have a precise date for this, but it was likely between 300 and 800 CE, though some studies suggest as last as 1266CE. A beautiful nation grew in isolation until 1778, when Captain Cook made contact.

These settlers were fishers and agriculturalists and imported some crops to the islands. They also modified estuaries and streams into fishponds. This aquaculture was highly advanced and existed with large-scale irrigation systems for crops (largely taro plants).

Hawaiian islands were structured into small towns, often with the same structures and buildings in each town. The most important were the temples, called heiau, of which there were two kinds. The mapele heiau were agricultural temples, while the luakini were war temples. There were also a number of houses for different purposes: the chief, storage, fishing, and a separate eating place for men and for women.

Hawaiian society was a caste-based system with some similarities to feudal Europe, except for the belief that the land was divine and thus could be taken care of, but not owned, by humans. Hawaiian economy was specialized to different islands (each its own kingdom with its own ruler)–O'ahu made cloth, Maui made canoes, Hawai'i dried fish.

posts.body:
The Chamorro

The Chamorro (CHamoru) are the indigenous people of the Mariana Islands, including Guam, as territory of the United States. People born in Guam are US citizens but do not vote in the presidential election of have representation in Congress. Guam was first settled about 3,500 years ago by travelers from Southeast Asia.

Chamorro legend says the universe was created by a twin brother and sister, out of the parts of the brother’s dying body. Another traditional belief is of the taotaomona, a spirit that protects the wilderness of the Mariana Islands.

Chamorro material culture was very advanced. Craftspeople were weavers and pot-makers, and their creations were beautiful and functional. The latte stone, now a symbol of Chamorro identity, was used as a pillar to support a raised building.

Chamorro society was matrilineal avunvuvlan (primary parents are mother and the mother’s brothers) and caste-based. All castes performed physical labor, but had unique duties.

[image description: a latte stone. A pillar, upon which sits a rounded rock with a smooth face. It is made of rough, gray rock.]

posts.body:
Greenlandic Inuit

November is National Native American Heritage Month!

The indigenous people of Greenland are Inuit. At 89%, they make up the majority of the Greenlandic population. Collectively, they are called Kalaallit Nunaat, and consist of three groups; Kalaallit (of western Greenland) being the largest, the Tunumiit (from eastern Greenland) and finally the Inughuit (of north Greenland, about 1% of the population of Greenland).

Greenland had actually been settled multiple times previous to this, always by boat from Canada. First was the Independence I/Saqqaq culture (2500-700 BCE). They were replaced by the Early Dorset (700 BCE-1 CE). The Late Dorset recolonized the northeastern part of the island in 700 CE.

In 980 CE, the first Norse arrived on Greenland (the first true European discovery of the Americas–500 years before Columbus). It was between 1000-1400 CE that the Thule began to settle Greenland. The Thule are the ancestors of modern Greenlandic Inuit.

An important form of artistic expression for Greenlandic Inuit culture and religion is the tupilaq, a figure made out of animal parts. None from prehistory are known to survive–all photographs are of tupilaq are of ones made after long-term European contact.

In 980 CE, the first Norse arrived on Greenland (the first true European discovery of the Americas–500 years before Columbus). It was between 1000-1400 CE that the Thule began to settle Greenland. The Thule are the ancestors of modern Greenlandic Inuit.

An important form of artistic expression for Greenlandic Inuit culture and religion is the tupilaq, a figure made out of animal parts. None from prehistory are known to survive–all photographs are of tupilaq are of ones made after long-term European contact.

posts.body:
The Aní-Kutánî

The Aní-Kutánî was a sociopolitical class of priests of the Cherokee (Aniyvwiya). A group of the Southeastern Woodlands, the Aniyvwiya has a complex hierarchy separating the leadership priestly and cultural activities from the leadership of warmongering ones.

The Aní-Kutánî, a hereditary clan of priests, was led by the head of civil and religious affairs and his seven counselors. Their roles included keeping oral traditions, maintaining a leadership role, and protecting the perpetual fire present in the council house.

Around the 13th century, the Aní-Kutánî became oppressive. Their actions were corrupt and self-serving. Eventually, one of the priests “attempted to take the wife of a man who was the brother of the leading chief of the nation” (Haywood, The Natural and Aboriginal History of Tennessee). The Aniyvwiya rose in rebellion, and the Aní-Kutánî were all killed in the mass uprising.

posts.body:
Native American Sign Languages

Native American groups had multiple regional sign-languages used for communication. Like spoken languages, sign languages have their own grammatical structure and vocabulary.

Hawai'i Sign Language (HSL) is the sign language of the Hawaiian Islands. While there are no attestations to its existance pre-American contact, HSL is considered an indigenous language is an primarily used be elderly people. It was recognized in the 1820s and is a language isolate–it shares no similarities to suggest it is part of American Sign Language (ASL). Not formally recognized until 2013, HSL has only about 30 native speakers and is considered ‘virtually extinct’. HSL is believed to be the last undiscovered language in the United States.

Inuit Sign Language (IUR) (Atgangmuurngniq or Uukturausingit) is the indigenous sign language of Inuit communities in the Canadian Arctic, most notably Nunavut. IUR works as both a trade language and as the primary language for Deaf Inuit. Certain communities with high levels of hereditary deafness use IUR frequently, and it functions as a primary language of the community.

Plateau Sign Language was a contact pidgin used across the Columbian Plateau (in what is now the US states of Washington, Oregon, and Idaho). As a contact language, it was used for trade and to communicate between groups with different languages. Plateau Sign Language went extint in the 18th century, and was replaced by…

Plains Sign Talk (PISL–Plains Indian Sign Language), at one point the lingua franca over central Canada, the United States, and northern Mexico, a region of over 1 million square miles (2.6 million square kilometers). PISL is a trade language and a contact language, and was also the daily usage language for Deaf people. One of the best studied indigenous sign languages, PISL was certainly fully formed before European arrival in the Americas.

Reading The Apache Diaspora is to see American history itself anew.”

posts.body:
The Haida Pantheon

The Haida are the indigenous people of Haida Gwaii, an archipelago off the coast of British Columbia, Canada.

Haida religion is well-preserved and understood. Many Haida believe in Ne-kilst-lass, who takes the form of a Raven. The Raven is generous and good, but can be a bit of a trickster. (Raven Tales are a shared point across nearly all indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast, Athabaskan-speaking peoples, and more of the First Nations tribes).

It was the Raven who formed the land and the heavens and released humans onto it, and gave humans water, food, and shelter. The Raven is not, however, a creator–the Raven redistributes and exchanges.

Other figures in the Haida pantheon include:

Ta'xet: god of violent death
Tia: goddess of peaceful death
Dazalarhons: a mortal woman who had been abused by her husband. she became the goddess of volcanos and punishes those who abuse others
Gyhldeptis: a forest goddess and protector

posts.body:
The Caddo Nation

The Caddo people first developed a unique material culture before 900 CE. They lived in the land that is now Arkansas, Louisiana, Texas, and Oklahoma.

The vibrant Caddo people were agriculturalists (primary crop was maize) who lived in large population centers along rivers. Their communities were important economic and diplomatic centers. The Caddo were historically mound-builders, like many other Mississippian cultures. Caddoan artistry was at its height during the 12th and 13th centuries, with a focus on fired earthware.

The most important mounds were the Spiro Mounds, in what is now southeastern Oklahoma. They are architecturally complex and artistically elaborate, and likely served multiple purposes and celebratory, ritual, and living spaces. Most people, however, lived in “beehive” grass houses. The Caddo were matrilineal and had a socially stratified society.

Caddoan culture is unbroken from prehistory to now. The prehistoric Caddo-language speakers are the direct ancestors of the modern Caddo Nation of Oklahoma (current population, about 6,000 enrolled members) and their histories–oral stories and dances–are likewise passed down in an unbroken chain.

Learn about the Caddo creation story here.

posts.body:
Native American Writing Systems

While the Maya had a unique form of writing and the Inca used the quipu, writing in Native American groups north of Mexico also existed. This writing was typically logographic picture-writing.

Most groups primarily relied on oral histories, and it is important to view these as equally important sources of information as written histories. However, this post is mainly written to address the misconception that oral histories were the only form of history.

The Mi'kmaq, a First Nations people in the Northeastern Woodlands, speak the Eastern Algonquian language also called Mi'kmaq. It was historically represented by petroglyphs and hieroglyphs. Hieroglyphic writing was often done using charcoal on birchbark.

Similarly, the Ojibwaishinaabe) people also had a written language. Multiple birchbark scrolls survive in the Oibwe language, one is pictured below.

The Lenape (Delaware) people speak multiple languages, the two most important being Munsee and Unami. They also utilized a form of picture-writing.

Most of these were supplemental to the strong oral tradition, but these examples of pre-European contact writing show that the cultures and histories of North America are just as diverse as any continent.

posts.body:
The Calusa

November is National Native American Heritage Month!

The Calusa (Cah-LOO-sah) were a people who lived in the Everglades region. In particular, the Caloosahatchee culture was a major power from 500-1700 CE, and were a regional power in European (Spanish) contact.

A complex society had formed by 880 CE, with high population densities and incredible architecture and art (largely ceramic pottery). The society was governed by a few leaders and had an apparently two-tiered stratified society. The main leader lived in a large manor on Mound Key, a man-made mound of oyster shells rising out of the water.

Their aquatic engineering was incredible. In addition to Mound Key, they engineered ingenious ways of catching fish. Most of their diet was fish. This is an important note–a prevailing idea from Afro-Eurasia is that civilizations must transition from hunter-gather-fishing societies to large-scale agriculture to ‘count’. However, the Calusa are an example of how this rule of thumb cannot always be applied, especially to American civilizations (another is the Caral-Supe civilization in what is now Peru).

The descendants of the Calusa still exist, likely in Cuba or having joined the nearby Seminole tribe.

posts.body:
Pre-contact Native American Connectivity

November is national Native American Heritage Month!

The indigenous people of the US and Canada lived in large groups, and those groups were connected with each other.

Many groups, like the contemporary nations of Europe, engaged in cycles of warfare and alliances. However, the warfare was generally less bloody, as they would fight until beaten, not ‘to the last man’, and the political leaders were more involved in the fighting than were European kings and emperors.

Treaties and alliances were common as well. The most famous example is the Haudenosaunee (Iroquois Confederacy), an alliance of five (later six) tribes in the Northeastern Woodlands. The unique political system there set the stage for, and was an important inspiration to, American democracy after 1776.

Trade spanned the continent for thousands of years. The Mississippi River was an important tradeway, and materials and goods moved thousands of miles along it. Civilizations would commonly have both materials from the Gulf of Mexico and copper from around the Great Lakes. When Europeans landed in what is now Massachusetts and were taught to coplant the Three Sisters, those three crops (maize, beans, squash) were all originally Mexican plants.

We also know that inter-tribal adoptions took place, as well as marriages.

The map of language families also elaborates the unique relations between tribes that existed far away from each other. The Athabaskan languages (a subgroup contained within the Na-Dené linguistic family) occur in Alaska and northwest Canada, a few spots on the Pacific Coast, and in a large cluster in what is now New Mexico and Texas.

[image description: a gray map of the US and Canada with regions of Athabaskans marked in red. By far the largest reason is covers Alaska and the left half of Canada, mostly inland and away from the coast. There are four small sports on the Pacific Coast in the US. There is another large hotspot near New Mexico and Texas, but it is more broken up than the Canada hotspot.]
